Subjective: Stress-related symptoms for a few months, worse daily for last 2 weeks. Main complaints: body tension, stiff muscles, heart palpitations, rapid breathing. Palpitations occur at rest (e.g., in bath, at night), last ~30 mins, resolve spontaneously. Rapid breathing also occurs at rest. Triggered by high-stress job (new doctor, internal medicine, understaffed, long days, uncertainty). Impact: Difficulty falling asleep due to worrying about work; sleeps ~6 hours/night. Better sleep on days off. Reports difficulty saying 'no' at work, feels guilt. Coping: reduces coffee, distraction with colleagues helps. Pertinent Negatives: No chest pain, no irregular heartbeat, no dizziness, no light-headedness, no symptoms on exertion, no abdominal complaints. Social: Recently graduated doctor, lives with housemates who are also doctors, good support system. ICE: Request to rule out physical cause (e.g., anemia); asks if talking to a professional would be good.
Objective: Vitals: BP 120/60, HR 65 bpm, O2 Sat 98%, RR 14/min. General: Calm. Lungs: Good breath sounds across all fields, no abnormal sounds. Heart: Normal heart sounds, no murmurs. Abdomen: Examination deferred, no complaints reported.
Assessment: Stress-related physical symptoms secondary to occupational stress. Rule out somatic causes including anemia and thyroid dysfunction.
Plan: 1. Labs: Blood test for hemoglobin, thyroid function, liver function, and kidney function. 2. Referral: Make an appointment with the mental health nurse; can be done today. 3. Lifestyle Advice: Actively schedule relaxation moments (walks, coffee, swimming). Maintain regular sleep schedule. 4. Work Advice: Consider contacting occupational health doctor for potential work schedule adjustments. 5. Follow-up/Safety Net: Check lab results online in 2 days. Return for another appointment if symptoms worsen or if new concerns arise.
